result.execSummary:
The defendant Andrew J Melius was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Conditions of extended supervision are the same as the conditions of probation.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or will discharge with outstanding financial obligations due, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due.

Defendant shall not possess/consume any controlled substance without a valid prescription.

Defendant shall not be present in any place where controlled substances are illegally purchased, consumed or sold.

Defendant shall participate in all counseling and/or treatment programs directed by the probation agent, including AODA assessment/treatment.

Defendant shall provide DNA sample.

Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.

Defendant shall submit to random drug screens, including blood, breath or urine.

Defenant shall notify any medial or healthcare provider of opiate addiction prior to obtaining a prescription.

timeConds.notes: With Huber privileges consistent with the rules of the jail while the inmate maintains a minimum security status. The defendant, at the discretion of the Sheriff, may perform community service work as an inmate worker in the county jail and shall earn statutory good time for same.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Andrew J Melius

records.descr: Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt: Def appears in custody & w/Atty Katherine Romanowich.  Atty Mark D. Bensen for State.  Joint recommendation.  Statements by counsel.  Court proceeds to sentencing.
Sentencing hearing on March 4, 2015 at 01:15 pm.

Def appears in custody & w/Atty Katherine Romanowich.  Atty Jeanette Kara Corbett for State.  Preliminary hearing waived.  Court binds defendant over for trial and State shall file an Information within 48 hours.  Defendant is currently on a PO hold and has previously waived revocation.  State moves to dismiss and read in Cts. 2 and 3 and 14-CF-546 and Court so orders.  Guilty plea entered on Ct. 1.  Court finds def guilty on Ct. 1.  Counsel agree to adjourn sentencing to a later date following determination of pending revocation.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for March 4, 2015 at 01:15 pm.

Def appears in custody & w/Atty Katherine Romanowich.  Atty Stephanie L Hanson for State.  Counsel's first appearance.  Defendant has another matter pending set for a motion hearing in Br. 4.  Adjourned for position on preliminary hearing.  Hearing scheduled for January 21, 2015 at 08:15 am.
Defendant shall not possess/consume any controlled substances without a prescription

Def appears in custody & w/Atty. Nadya Perez Reyes from the State Public Defenders Office.  Atty Mandy A. Schepper for State.  Co-defendant case with Kyle Welleman.  Def given complaint, advised of charges, penalties and rights, and probable cause found.  Defendant is on a PO hold.  State requests cash bond.  $2,500 signature bond set.  Atty. Romanowich represents Defendant.  Preliminary hearing time limits waived.  Adjourned for position on preliminary hearing and to appear with counsel.  OTP may be necessary.  Hearing scheduled for December 17, 2014 at 08:15 am.
